awd_titl_txt: CAREER: CDS&E: One- and Two-Dimensional Fourier Transform Approaches for Characterizing Nano-Assemblies with Ion Mobility-Mass Spectrometry
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor James Prell at the University of Oregon is developing analytical methods for accurately determining the composition of mixtures of large polymers and/or molecular assemblies using mass spectrometry. Mass spectrometry is a tool for chemical analysis conventionally used to measure the mass and determine the structure of many types of molecules. Complex mixtures are a major target of research in industrial and biochemical applications as well as from the perspective of fundamental science. These mixtures can have properties that depend strongly on the relative amounts of their different constituents as well as how they are assembled. From synthetic chemicals to models of biological membranes, such systems can be extremely challenging to characterize using mass spectrometry or any other technique. Dr. Prell and his group are developing new approaches for these characterization challenges, ultimately seeking to facilitate precise control of physical and chemical properties. The project combines state-of-the-art mass spectrometry with advanced mathematical and signal processing tools. Publicly available, open-source software created as part of this project will be made available for researchers around the world to use in analyzing these types of samples. At the same time, Dr. Prell seeks to increase the participation of undergraduates from diverse backgrounds in STEM research through a research-based workshop course. Students in this course are learning and implementing strategies for communicating science research to audiences ranging from middle school through professional colleagues at regional and national STEM conferences.

Dr. Prell is establishing a vigorous, integrated program of research and education to simplify the analysis of nanoscale chemical assemblies using mass spectrometry, and to increase the retention and research participation of STEM undergraduates from underrepresented groups. There are three specific aims: 1) to establish Fourier Transform-based methodology for analyzing extremely congested electrospray mass spectra of mixed-subunit nanoassemblies, including copolymers and lipoprotein assemblies; 2) to introduce two-dimensional Fourier Transform-based measurement tools for signal isolation in extremely congested electrospray mass spectra of nanoassemblies for which prior ion mobility separation or ordinary Fourier Transform are insufficient; and 3) to increase undergraduate participation in and communication of scientific research. Measurement tools target characterization of subunit interactions, assembly shape and size, and assembly kinetics in a wide variety of applications related to the study of nanoassemblies. Software being developed is open-source and publicly available, allowing rapid implementation and adaptation by other research groups. Educational goals are being addressed by implementing a 1-credit workshop course for undergraduates at the University of Oregon using themes drawn from this research as prototypes. Students in the course develop "elevator talks" for delivery to a UO STEM bridge program; local middle- and high school outreach modules; and a research presentation abstract for submission to a regional or national scientific conference. These efforts build off of the PI's expertise in mass spectrometry and experience supporting URM student representation and inclusion in science as a faculty sponsor of UO's chapter of the Society for the Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Goals

          The major goals of this project included the use of Fourier ("1-dimensional") and Gabor ("2-dimensional") Transform-based data analysis to understand mass spectra of chemical samples that are extremely difficult to interpret by conventional means, production of open-source software available to researchers around the world, and enhancement of undergraduate education in science presentation skills.

Intellectual Merit

          Mass spectrometry is the technique whereby masses of molecules and their assemblies are determined by ionizing and separating them in the gas phase. This technique can identify and quantify different molecular species with very high precision and accuracy, but the number of signals arising from different species can be overwhelming for conventional manual and automated analysis methods for large assemblies or highly heterogeneous mixtures. This research addressed several major challenges associated with such samples through:

  1. Development of an analytical framework for interpreting mass spectra of highly heterogeneous chemical sample using Fourier and Gabor Transform methods. The relationship between "frequency" data arising from mass spectra and the masses and charge states of the ion population was characterized, including the meaning of Fourier/Gábor phase information in terms of sample composition, and limitations and uncertainties arising from this framework were explored. This framework also included a general classification of different types of heterogeneity that can be present in chemical samples and their expected manifestations in mass spectra.
  2. Production of a regularly updated, open-source, publicly available software suite (iFAMS, "interactive Fourier-Transform Analysis for Mass Spectrometry") and accompanying tutorials for researchers around the world. iFAMS is currently available in a stable Graphical User Interface version (v. 6.3) at https://github.com/prellgroup/iFAMS/releases.
  3. Demonstration of the capabilities and advantages of iFAMS across a broad range of cutting-edge samples. These included single- and mixed-lipid lipoprotein "nanodisc" samples, mixed-protein samples, polymers and copolymers, and antibody drug samples in serum matrix. This research revealed numerous unique advantages of iFAMS software for analyzing the samples as compared to conventional data analysis methods, including examples where the type of information obtained (such as the simultaneous subunit composition and mass distribution of copolymers, lipids in mixed-lipid nanodiscs, and coexisting oligomeric states of membrane proteins within detergent micelles) could be extremely difficult or virtually impossible to access with other state-of-the-art methods. For example, iFAMS is uniquely able to distinguish between mixed-lipid nanodisc samples with the same bulk lipid stoichiometry but different heterogeneity types.

This research resulted in 9 publications in peer-reviewed journals, two more manuscripts in preparation at the time of reporting, ~40 public presentations, an open-source publicly available Python-based software suite, and a licensable version of the software capable of interacting directly with vendor-proprietary mass spectrometry data files. This output included collaborations with the pharmaceutical industry, an analytical instrument manufacturer, a clinical collaborator, and several universities.

Broader Impacts

          This research has major and broad implications in the chemical and pharmaceutical manufacturing industries as well as in both mass spectrometry fundamentals and clinical applications. For example, iFAMS software enables polymer manufacturers to characterize chemical conversion of functionalized polymers in unprecedented detail, and the composition and stoichiometry of nanometer-scale lipid bilayer mimics, such as nanodiscs, commonly used in the study of membrane proteins, can be analyzed with high accuracy and precision. In addition to performing as well as other state-of-the-art methods for quantitating antibody drugs in serum samples, iFAMS software can also rapidly identify contaminants that can lead to analysis errors. As the resolving power and sensitivity of mass spectrometers continue to improve, Fourier/Gabor Transform-based theory and methodology developed here provide crucial means to enhance the amount of information that can be extracted for an extremely broad variety of challenging samples. 4 undergraduates, 4 PhD students, and 1 MS student were trained in the PI's group in advanced analytical chemistry and mass spectrometry techniques as well as science presentation skills through this project.

          This project also included an Educational Program for enhancing undergraduate science presentation skills while simultaneously increasing opportunities for and visibility of STEM students from historically underrepresented groups. Part of this Program was a specially designed workshop course, called "Communicating Science," for undergraduate STEM students at the University of Oregon, in which students practiced short-form "elevator talks" about their research, developed and led a hands-on science outreach modules with local middle schoolers, learned effective visual presentation skills, and wrote abstracts based on their research to submit to extramural STEM conferences. The PI, who has been the faculty advisor to university's chapter of Society for the Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS) since 2014, also co-led an effort to take 68 students (31 undergraduate, 37 PhD) from the University of Oregon to the SACNAS National Diversity in STEM Conference in Portland, OR, in 2023, as well as ~20 students in years prior, including students from the workshop course.

 


Last Modified: 12/02/2024
Modified by: James S Prell

Project Outcomes Report


Goals


 The major goals of this project included the use of Fourier ("1-dimensional") and Gabor ("2-dimensional") Transform-based data analysis to understand mass spectra of chemical samples that are extremely difficult to interpret by conventional means, production of open-source software available to researchers around the world, and enhancement of undergraduate education in science presentation skills.


Intellectual Merit


 Mass spectrometry is the technique whereby masses of molecules and their assemblies are determined by ionizing and separating them in the gas phase. This technique can identify and quantify different molecular species with very high precision and accuracy, but the number of signals arising from different species can be overwhelming for conventional manual and automated analysis methods for large assemblies or highly heterogeneous mixtures. This research addressed several major challenges associated with such samples through:

 Development of an analytical framework for interpreting mass spectra of highly heterogeneous chemical sample using Fourier and Gabor Transform methods. The relationship between "frequency" data arising from mass spectra and the masses and charge states of the ion population was characterized, including the meaning of Fourier/Gbor phase information in terms of sample composition, and limitations and uncertainties arising from this framework were explored. This framework also included a general classification of different types of heterogeneity that can be present in chemical samples and their expected manifestations in mass spectra.
Production of a regularly updated, open-source, publicly available software suite (iFAMS, "interactive Fourier-Transform Analysis for Mass Spectrometry") and accompanying tutorials for researchers around the world. iFAMS is currently available in a stable Graphical User Interface version (v. 6.3) at https://github.com/prellgroup/iFAMS/releases.
Demonstration of the capabilities and advantages of iFAMS across a broad range of cutting-edge samples. These included single- and mixed-lipid lipoprotein "nanodisc" samples, mixed-protein samples, polymers and copolymers, and antibody drug samples in serum matrix. This research revealed numerous unique advantages of iFAMS software for analyzing the samples as compared to conventional data analysis methods, including examples where the type of information obtained (such as the simultaneous subunit composition and mass distribution of copolymers, lipids in mixed-lipid nanodiscs, and coexisting oligomeric states of membrane proteins within detergent micelles) could be extremely difficult or virtually impossible to access with other state-of-the-art methods. For example, iFAMS is uniquely able to distinguish between mixed-lipid nanodisc samples with the same bulk lipid stoichiometry but different heterogeneity types.
 


This research resulted in 9 publications in peer-reviewed journals, two more manuscripts in preparation at the time of reporting, ~40 public presentations, an open-source publicly available Python-based software suite, and a licensable version of the software capable of interacting directly with vendor-proprietary mass spectrometry data files. This output included collaborations with the pharmaceutical industry, an analytical instrument manufacturer, a clinical collaborator, and several universities.


Broader Impacts


 This research has major and broad implications in the chemical and pharmaceutical manufacturing industries as well as in both mass spectrometry fundamentals and clinical applications. For example, iFAMS software enables polymer manufacturers to characterize chemical conversion of functionalized polymers in unprecedented detail, and the composition and stoichiometry of nanometer-scale lipid bilayer mimics, such as nanodiscs, commonly used in the study of membrane proteins, can be analyzed with high accuracy and precision. In addition to performing as well as other state-of-the-art methods for quantitating antibody drugs in serum samples, iFAMS software can also rapidly identify contaminants that can lead to analysis errors. As the resolving power and sensitivity of mass spectrometers continue to improve, Fourier/Gabor Transform-based theory and methodology developed here provide crucial means to enhance the amount of information that can be extracted for an extremely broad variety of challenging samples. 4 undergraduates, 4 PhD students, and 1 MS student were trained in the PI's group in advanced analytical chemistry and mass spectrometry techniques as well as science presentation skills through this project.


 This project also included an Educational Program for enhancing undergraduate science presentation skills while simultaneously increasing opportunities for and visibility of STEM students from historically underrepresented groups. Part of this Program was a specially designed workshop course, called "Communicating Science," for undergraduate STEM students at the University of Oregon, in which students practiced short-form "elevator talks" about their research, developed and led a hands-on science outreach modules with local middle schoolers, learned effective visual presentation skills, and wrote abstracts based on their research to submit to extramural STEM conferences.
